name.text: 8.3.3.4 3x3 linear system infinite solutions Gauss Elimination

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ {@eqq3@} \\ \end{matrix}\]

You might need to think carefully about this system

  1. Construct the augmented matrix.
    2. \([A|B]=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Triangularise the augmented matrix by means of row operations. Express your answer as matrix \(T\).
    3. \(T=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]
  3. Apply back-substitution to obtain the solution to the system.
    4. \(X=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]].
[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. The augmented matrix is \[ [A|B] = {@matAugmented@}. \]

  2. To triangularize the augmented matrix, we begin from the augmented matrix \( [A|B] \). Since \( a_{11} = {@matAugmented[1][1]@} \neq 0 \), we can replace row 2 by row 2 - \( \frac{{@matAugmented[2][1]@}}{{@matAugmented[1][1]@}} \times \) (row 1) and row 3 by row 3 - \( \frac{{@matAugmented[3][1]@}}{{@matAugmented[1][1]@}} \times \) (row 1). In other words, \[ [A|B] = {@matAugmented@} \begin{matrix} \\ R2 - \frac{{@matAugmented[2][1]@}}{{@matAugmented[1][1]@}} \times R1 \\ R3 - \frac{{@matAugmented[3][1]@}}{{@matAugmented[1][1]@}} \times R1 \\ \end{matrix} \Rightarrow {@matGauss1@}. \] By continuing this process, we get the triangularization \( T \) of \( [A|B] \): \[T = {@matT@} \].

  3. The third row of the matrix is a zero row, so we are left with an undetermined system of equations. Therefore, there are infinitely many solutions. Set \(z = t \) in the second equation \({@eqTrian2@} \) to obtain \[ {@eqTrian2BackSubst@} \] from which we deduce \(y = {@ySol@} \). Plugging in the obtained values of \( y \) and \( z \) in the first equation \( {@eqTrian1@} \) we obtain \[ {@eqTrian1BackSubst@} \] from which we deduce \(x = {@xSol@} \). Summarizing, \[ x = {@xSol@}, \qquad y = {@ySol@}, \qquad z = t. \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Careful, augmented matrix has not been introduced correctly.
(b), (c) The triangularisation didn't result in an upper triangular matrix. This also means that it is not possible to do back-substitution.
(c) There is an error in the back-substitution. Your answer doesn't satisfy the equations \[ {@Aans2@} {@ans3@} = {@Aans2 . ans3@} \neq {@Bans2@} \]

truefeedback.text: (c) Back-substitution done correctly. You've identified all the solutions.

falsefeedback.text: (c) Back-substitution partially correct. You've identified a right answer, but there are more. What form does the triangular matrix have?
(b) The triangularized matrix and the augmented matrix are not Gauss equivalent.
(b) The triangularized matrix and the augmented matrix are not Gauss equivalent.
